head.title: The Court's Term Is Over, but Not the Discord; The Miranda Ruling

identified-content.classifier: Miranda V Arizona (US Supreme Court 1966 Decision)

hedline.hl1: The Court's Term Is Over, but Not the Discord; The Miranda Ruling

abstract.p: Allan Nadler letter on Supreme Court ruling upholding Miranda warnings; says it would be better to disqualify all self-incriminating statements not made in presence of officer of the court

block.p: Re ''Miranda's Value in the Trenches,'' by Scott Turow (Op-Ed, June 28):
Re ''Miranda's Value in the Trenches,'' by Scott Turow (Op-Ed, June 28):

Mr. Turow acknowledges that Miranda has ''little practical impact'' on the daily functioning of the legal system, because ''courts and cops have accommodated themselves to the rule.'' But to assert that Miranda assures all citizens, rich and poor, educated and not, the ''same critical knowledge about how the system works'' is naive.
The perfunctory reading of rights to a criminal suspect while he is being forcibly handcuffed and pushed into a police cruiser is often incomprehensible to the suspect.
A better arrangement would be simply to disqualify all self-incriminating statements not made in the presence of an officer of the court.
The writer is an associate professor of Jewish studies, Drew University.
